text:
Explore (Digging In)

Providing for Individual Needs

As you move around the room listening to students discuss the problem, listen for strategies students use to make sense of using the table to answer ratio questions.

Suggested Questions

  • how can you use the table to find the costs for 20 boxes? 60 boxes? 12 boxes?
  • How do you think henry found the cost of 1 box?

• Answers will vary. See examples that follow for how some students may think about using the table representation.
  • Answers will vary. Students should be able to use the table and the patterns they have found to "go backward" on the table or to divide the amount of money collected by the number of boxes to get the price for 1 box.

Students are still new to table representations. They may feel that they are restricted to keeping the pattern of increasing the number of boxes sold by 5 and the money by $60.

Tables are flexible representations. Students can make jumps in the table as they need. For example, they can use multiplicative reasoning to fill in values on a table. Students might reason in ways similar to the ways that they have used factors and multiples in previous problems.
